creator: BeornsBeard
title: Squirting Scuba Helmet
materials_required: Plastic tubes that fit around the pump
description: This project details how to construct a timer-based, water-pump-powered scuba helmet capable of misting or spraying water at set intervals. The helmet can be adapted for use as a wearable garden or as a personal space tool, depending on the nozzles used.
steps: Print and pre-crease the pepakura file. If you have a large head, increase the file size in Illustrator before printing. Use a bone folding knife to pre-crease all the folding edges.
Cut out the paper sections, fold them, and glue them together according to the pepakura model. Build the helmet in halves and then glue the two halves together.

Apply fiberglass to the outside of the helmet in a well-ventilated area. Cut 3-inch squares of fiberglass, mix resin with hardener, and dab the resin onto the helmet. Apply the fiberglass squares, dabbing with resin until they sit flat. Repeat until the entire helmet is covered, allowing the resin to cure between sections if needed.
Sand the fiberglassed helmet to remove stray strands and level the surface. Wear a particle filter during sanding.

Apply automotive body filler to round out the shape of the helmet. Mix small amounts of filler with hardener and apply thin coats to avoid bubbles. Sand the filler with 60 grit sandpaper to remove excess and then smooth with 180 grit sandpaper.
Paint the helmet with spray paint of your choice. Optionally, apply black acrylic paint for detailing to give it a tarnished appearance.
Upload the provided Arduino code to an Arduino Uno. This code will control the water pump, running it for ten seconds and then turning it off for a set period.

Solder wires to the relay according to the instructions: green to common pin and 9V snap, blue to coil pin and Arduino ground, red to coil pin and Arduino pin 13, black to normally open pin and water pump positive wire. Insulate all cords to prevent shorts.

Connect the water pump to the misting tubes. Ensure a snug fit between tubes, using shrink tube or duct tape if needed. Attach the misting heads to the tubes inside the helmet, running the tube down the helmet and connecting to the pump.
Test the system to ensure everything fits and doesn't leak. Place the Arduino in a waterproof case or plastic bag. Attach a 9V battery. Verify that the pump runs and sprays water.
